text: Standard 1: The Scientific Process: SCIENTIFIC INVESTIGATION—Discover, invent, and investigate using the skills necessary to engage in the scientific process

children.text: SCIENTIFIC INQUIRY
Use the senses to make observations
Ask questions about the world around them
Collect data about living and non-living things
Collect, record, and organize data using simple tools, equipment, and techniques safely
Explain the results of an investigation to an audience using simple data organizers (e.g., charts, graphs, pictures)
Develop predictions based on observations
Conduct a simple investigation using a systematic process safely to test a prediction
Pose a question and develop a hypothesis based on observations
Safely collect and analyze data to answer a question
Describe a testable hypothesis and an experimental procedure
Identify the variables in scientific investigations and recognize the importance of controlling variables in scientific experiments
Formulate and defend conclusions based on evidence
Formulate a testable hypothesis that can be answered through a controlled experiment
Use appropriate tools, equipment, and techniques safely to collect, display, and analyze data
Design and safely conduct a scientific investigation to answer a question or test a hypothesis
Explain the importance of replicable trials
Determine the link(s) between evidence and the conclusion(s) of an investigation
Communicate the significant components of the experimental design and results of a scientific investigation
SCIENTIFIC KNOWLEDGE
Differentiate between an observation and an inference
Explain the need to revise conclusions and explanations based on new scientific evidence

text: Standard 2: The Scientific Process: NATURE OF SCIENCE-—Understand that science, technology, and society are interrelated

children.text: SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, AND SOCIETY
Identify different types of technologies at home, in the classroom, and/or in the world
Explain why people create technological devices
Describe ways technologies in fields such as agriculture, information, manufacturing, or communication have influenced society
Describe how the use of technology has influenced the economy, demography, and environment of Hawaii
Explain how technology has an impact on society and science
Explain how the needs of society have influenced the development and use of technologies
Explain the use of reliable print and electronic sources to provide scientific information and evidence
Describe significant relationships among society, science, and technology and how one impacts the other
UNIFYING CONCEPTS AND THEMES
Describe a variety of changes that occur in nature
Describe changes that have occurred in society as a result of new technologies
Use models and/or simulations to represent and investigate features of objects, events, and processes in the real world
Describe how scale and mathematical models can be used to support and explain scientific data

text: Standard 3: Life and Environmental Sciences: ORGANISMS AND THE ENVIRONMENT—Understand the unity, diversity, and interrelationships of organisms, including their relationship to cycles of matter and energy in the environment

children.text: INTERDEPENDENCE
Identify similarities and differences between plants and animals
Describe how animals depend on plants and animals
Describe how plants depend on animals
Describe how an organism's behavior is determined by its environment
Describe the interdependent relationships among producers, consumers, and decomposers in an ecosystem in terms of the cycles of matter
Explain the interaction and dependence of organisms on one another
Explain how biotic and abiotic factors affect the carrying capacity and sustainability of an ecosystem
CYCLES OF MATTER AND ENERGY
Identify the requirements of plants and animals to survive (e.g., food, air, light, water)
Explain how simple food chains and food webs can be traced back to plants
Describe the cycle of energy among producers, consumers, and decomposers
Describe how matter and energy are transferred within and among living systems and their physical environment
Explain how energy moves through food webs, including the roles of photosynthesis and cellular respiration

text: Standard 4: Life and Environmental Sciences: STRUCTURE AND FUNCTION IN ORGANISMS—Understand the structures and functions of living organisms and how organisms can be compared scientifically

children.text: CLASSIFICATION
Identify differences between living and non-living things
Describe how living things have structures that help them to survive
Explain how plants and animals go through life cycles
Classify organisms according to their degree of relatedness
CELLS, TISSUES, ORGANS, AND ORGAN SYSTEMS
Compare distinct structures of living things that help them to survive
Identify the basic differences between plant cells and animal cells
Describe the structures of the human body and how they work together to sustain life
Describe the cell theory
Describe the basic structure and function of various types of cells
Describe the levels of organization in organisms

text: Standard 5: Life and Environmental Sciences: DIVERSITY, GENETICS, AND EVOLUTION—Understand genetics and biological evolution and their impact on the unity and diversity of organisms

children.text: HEREDITY
Identify ways in which some offspring are very much like their parents, although not exactly
Identify ways in which the same kinds of plants and the same kinds of animals differ
Recognize that some traits of living things are inherited and others are learned
Differentiate between sexual and asexual reproduction
Describe how an inherited trait can be determined by one or more genes which are found on chromosomes
Explain that small differences between parents and offspring could produce descendants that look very different from their ancestors
UNITY AND DIVERSITY
Describe the physical characteristics of living things that enable them to live in their environment
Identify distinct environments and the different kinds of organisms each environment supports
Describe the relationship between structure and function in organisms
Describe the roles of various organisms in the same environment
Describe how different organisms need specific environmental conditions to survive
Analyze how organisms' body structures contribute to their ability to survive and reproduce
Explain why variation(s) in a species' gene pool contributes to its survival in a constantly changing environment
BIOLOGICAL EVOLUTION
Compare fossils and living things
Explain how fossils provide evidence that life and environmental conditions have changed over time
Describe how changes in the physical environment affect the survival of organisms

text: Standard 6: Physical, Earth, and Space Sciences: NATURE OF MATTER AND ENERGY—Understand the nature of matter and energy, forms of energy (including waves) and energy transformations, and their significance in understanding the structure of the universe

children.text: NATURE OF MATTER
Classify objects by their attributes (e.g., physical properties, materials of which they are made)
Identify solids, liquids, and gases and their basic properties
Identify ways to change the physical properties of objects
Describe how some materials may be combined to form new substances
Explain how matter can change physical or chemical forms, but the total amount of matter remains constant
Describe and compare the physical and chemical properties of different substances
Describe the organization of the periodic table
Recognize changes that indicate that a chemical reaction has taken place
Describe matter using the atomic model
ENERGY AND ITS TRANSFORMATION
Define energy and explain that the sun produces energy in the form of light and heat
Explain what is needed for electricity to flow in a circuit to create light and sound
Identify different forms of energy (e.g., thermal, electrical, nuclear, light, sound) and how they can change and transfer energy from one form to another
Describe ways that heat can be transferred from one object to another
Compare how heat energy can be transferred through conduction, convection, and radiation
Describe the different types of energy transformations
Explain how energy can change forms and is conserved
Describe and give examples of different types of energy waves
WAVES
Explain how things make sound through vibrations
Explain how light traveling in a straight line changes when it reaches an object
Compare what happens to light when it is reflected, refracted, and absorbed
Explain how vibrations in materials set up wavelike disturbances that spread away from the source
Explain the relationship between the color of light and wavelength within the electromagnetic spectrum
Explain how seismic waves provide scientists with information about the structure of Earth's interior
Identify the characteristics and properties of mechanical and electromagnetic waves

text: Standard 7: Physical, Earth, and Space Sciences: FORCE AND MOTION—Understand the relationship between force, mass, and motion of objects; and know the major natural forces: gravitational, electric, and magnetic

children.text: FORCES AND MOTION
Identify that objects that will fall to the ground unless something is holding them up
Describe how the motion of an object can be changed by force (push or pull)
Identify the properties of magnets
Compare how simple machines do work to make life easier
Describe examples of how forces affect an object's motion
FORCES OF THE UNIVERSE
Describe that the mass of the Earth exerts a gravitational force on all objects
Explain how electrically charged materials can push or pull other charged materials
Explain that electric currents can produce magnetic effects and that magnets can cause electric currents
Explain that every object has mass and therefore exerts a gravitational force on other objects

text: Standard 8: Physical, Earth, and Space Sciences: EARTH AND SPACE SCIENCE—Understand the Earth and its processes, the solar system, and the universe and its contents

children.text: FORCES THAT SHAPE THE EARTH
Report and describe weather changes from day to day and over the seasons
Describe how the water cycle is related to weather and climate
Describe how slow processes sometimes shape and reshape the surface of the Earth
Describe how fast processes (e.g., volcanoes, earthquakes) sometimes shape and reshape the surface of the Earth
Explain how the sun is the major source of energy influencing climate and weather on Earth
Explain the concepts of continental drift and plate tectonics
Explain the relationship between density and convection currents in the ocean and atmosphere
Describe the physical characteristics of oceans
THE UNIVERSE
Identify different types of celestial objects seen in the day and night sky
Describe that the sun warms the land, air, and water
Safely observe and describe the basic movements of the sun and moon
Describe that constellations stay the same, though they "appear" to move across the night sky
Describe the composition of objects in the galaxy
Explain the predictable motions of the Earth and moon
Compare the characteristics and movement patterns of the planets in our solar system
Describe the major components of the universe
Describe the role of gravitational force in the motions of planetary systems
EARTH MATERIALS
Identify different Earth materials and classify them by their physical properties
Identify the limited supply of natural resources and how they can be extended through conservation, reuse, and recycling
Describe different Earth materials (e.g., rocks, minerals, sand, soil) and explain their formation and composition
Compare the characteristics of the three main types of rocks
Illustrate the rock cycle and explain how igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary rocks are formed
EARTH IN THE SOLAR SYSTEM
Describe the relationship between the sun and the Earth's daily rotation and annual revolution
Describe the relationship (size and distance) of Earth to other components in the solar system
Describe examples of what astronomers have discovered using telescopes
Explain that the planets orbit the sun and that the moon orbits the Earth
Demonstrate that day and night are caused by the rotation of the Earth on its axis
Describe how the Earth's motions and tilt on its axis affect the seasons and weather patterns
Standard 1: The Scientific Process: SCIENTIFIC INVESTIGATION—Discover, invent, and investigate using the skills necessary to engage in the scientific process
SCIENTIFIC INQUIRY
Describe how a testable hypothesis may need to be revised to guide a scientific investigation
Design and safely implement an experiment, including the appropriate use of tools and techniques to organize, analyze, and validate data
Defend and support conclusions, explanations, and arguments based on logic, scientific knowledge, and evidence from data
Determine the connection(s) among hypotheses, scientific evidence, and conclusions
Communicate the components of a scientific investigation, using appropriate techniques
Engage in and explain the importance of peer review in science
SCIENTIFIC KNOWLEDGE
Revise, as needed, conclusions and explanations based on new evidence
Describe the importance of ethics and integrity in scientific investigation
Explain how scientific explanations must meet a set of established criteria to be considered valid
Standard 2: The Scientific Process: NATURE OF SCIENCE—Understand that science, technology, and society are interrelated
SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, AND SOCIETY
Explain how scientific advancements and emerging technologies have influenced society
Compare the risks and benefits of potential solutions to technological issues

Standard 3: Life and Environmental Sciences: ORGANISMS AND THE ENVIRONMENT—Understand the unity, diversity, and interrelationships of organisms, including their relationship to cycles of matter and energy in the environment
Standard 4: Life and Environmental Sciences: STRUCTURE AND FUNCTION IN ORGANISMS—Understand the structures and functions of living organisms and how organisms can be compared scientifically
Standard 5: Life and Environmental Sciences: DIVERSITY, GENETICS, AND EVOLUTION—Understand genetics and biological evolution and their impact on the unity and diversity of organisms

Standard 6: Physical, Earth and Space Science: NATURE OF MATTER AND ENERGY—Understand the nature of matter and energy, forms of energy (including waves) and energy transformations, and their significance in understanding the structure of the universe
ENERGY AND ITS TRANSFORMATION
Describe endothermic and exothermic chemical reactions
Explain how the law of conservation of energy is applied to various systems
Describe different examples of the concept of entropy
Explain that changes in thermal energy can lead to a phase change of matter
Describe nuclear reactions and how they produce energy
WAVES
Compare transverse and longitudinal waves and their properties
Explain and provide examples of electromagnetic radiation and sound using a wave model
NATURE OF MATTER
Explain how elements are arranged in the periodic table and describe trends among elemental properties
Describe interactions among molecules
Describe the factors that affect the rate of chemical reactions
Explain how atoms bond using valence electrons
Describe a variety of chemical reactions

Standard 7: Physical, Earth, and Space Sciences: FORCE AND MOTION—Understand the relationship between force, mass, and motion of objects; and know the major natural forces: gravitational, electric, and magnetic
FORCES AND MOTION
Apply the laws of motion to determine the effects of forces on the linear motion of objects
Use vectors to explain force and motion
FORCES OF THE UNIVERSE
Explain the relationship among the gravitational force, the mass of the objects, and the distance between objects
Explain the magnetic and electric forces in the universe
Standard 8: Physical, Earth, and Space Sciences: EARTH AND SPACE SCIENCE—Understand the Earth and its processes, the solar system, and the universe and its contents

SCIENTIFIC INQUIRY
Describe how a testable hypothesis may need to be revised to guide a scientific investigation
Design and safely implement an experiment, including the appropriate use of tools and techniques to organize, analyze, and validate data
Defend and support conclusions, explanations, and arguments based on logic, scientific knowledge, and evidence from data
Determine the connection(s) among hypotheses, scientific evidence, and conclusions
Communicate the components of a scientific investigation, using appropriate techniques
Engage in and explain the importance of peer review in science
SCIENTIFIC KNOWLEDGE
Revise, as needed, conclusions and explanations based on new evidence
Describe the importance of ethics and integrity in scientific investigation
Explain how scientific explanations must meet a set of established criteria to be considered valid
Standard 2: The Scientific Process: NATURE OF SCIENCE—Understand that science, technology, and society are interrelated
SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, AND SOCIETY
Explain how scientific advancements and emerging technology have influenced society
Compare the risks and benefits of potential solutions to technological issues

Standard 3: Life and Environmental Sciences: ORGANISMS AND THE ENVIRONMENT—Understand the unity, diversity, and interrelationships of organisms, including their relationship to cycles of matter and energy in the environment
CYCLES OF MATTER AND ENERGY
Describe biogeochemical cycles within ecosystems
Explain the chemical reactions that occur in photosynthesis and cellular respiration that result in cycling of energy
Explain how matter and energy flow through living systems and the physical environment
INTERDEPENDENCE
Explain dynamic equilibrium in organisms, populations, and ecosystems; explain the effect of equilibrium shifts
Standard 4: Life and Environmental Sciences: STRUCTURE AND FUNCTION IN ORGANISMS—Understand the structures and functions of living organisms and how organisms can be compared scientifically
CELLS, TISSUES, ORGANS, AND ORGAN SYSTEMS
Describe different cell parts and their functions
Explain how cells are specialized into different tissues and organs
Differentiate between the processes of mitosis and meiosis
Describe how homeostatic balance occurs in cells and organisms
Describe the components and functions of a variety of macromolecules active in biological systems
CLASSIFICATION
Explain the organization of life on Earth using the modern classification system
Standard 5: Life and Environmental Sciences: DIVERSITY, GENETICS, AND EVOLUTION—Understand genetics and biological evolution and their impact on the unity and diversity of organisms
BIOLOGICAL EVOLUTION
Explain the theory of evolution and describe evidence that supports this theory
Explain the theory of natural selection
UNITY AND DIVERSITY
Explain the structural properties of DNA and the role of DNA in heredity and protein synthesis
Explain how Mendel's laws of heredity can be used to determine the traits of possible offspring
Explain chromosomal mutations, their possible causes, and their effects on genetic variation

Standard 6: Physical, Earth, and Space Sciences: NATURE OF MATTER AND ENERGY—Understand the nature of matter and energy, forms of energy (including waves) and energy transformations, and their significance in understanding the structure of the universe

Standard 7: Physical, Earth, and Space Sciences: FORCE AND MOTION—Understand the relationship between force, mass, and motion of objects; and know the major natural forces: gravitational, electric, and magnetic
Standard 8: Physical, Earth, and Space Sciences: EARTH AND SPACE SCIENCE—Understand the Earth and its processes, the solar system, and the universe and its contents

Design and safely implement an experiment, including the appropriate use of tools and techniques to organize, analyze, and validate data
Defend and support conclusions, explanations, and arguments based on logic, scientific knowledge, and evidence from data

Communicate the components of a scientific investigation, using appropriate techniques

Revise, as needed, conclusions and explanations based on new evidence
Describe the importance of ethics and integrity in scientific investigation

Standard 2: The Scientific Process: NATURE OF SCIENCE—Understand that science, technology, and society are interrelated
SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, AND SOCIETY
Explain how scientific advancements and emerging technology have influenced society
Compare the risks and benefits of potential solutions to technological issues
Explain the impact of humans on the Earth system
Describe technologies used to collect information about the universe

Standard 3: Life and Environmental Sciences: ORGANISMS AND THE ENVIRONMENT—Understand the unity, diversity, and interrelationships of organisms, including their relationship to cycles of matter and energy in the environment
Standard 4: Life and Environmental Sciences: STRUCTURE AND FUNCTION IN ORGANISMS—Understand the structures and functions of living organisms and how organisms can be compared scientifically

Standard 7: Physical, Earth, and Space Sciences: FORCE AND MOTION— Understand the relationship between force, mass, and motion of objects; and know the major natural forces: gravitational, electric, and magnetic
Standard 8: Physical, Earth, and Space Sciences: EARTH AND SPACE SCIENCE—Understand the Earth and its processes, the solar system, and the universe and its contents
FORCES THAT SHAPE THE EARTH
Describe how elements and water move through solid Earth, the oceans, atmosphere, and living things as part of geochemical cycles
Describe how to estimate geologic time
Describe how heat and energy transfer into and out of the atmosphere and their involvement in global climate
Explain the effects of movements of crustal plates
Describe how winds and ocean currents are produced on the Earth's surface
Describe climate and weather patterns associated with certain geographic locations and features
EARTH IN THE SOLAR SYSTEM
Explain the possible origins and evolution of the solar system
Describe the major internal and external sources of energy on Earth
THE UNIVERSE
Describe the physical and nuclear dynamics involved in the life cycle of a star
Compare different theories concerning the formation of the universe
